==History==
 
==History==
    −
The formal study of ethics began with the early Greeks and later by the Romans. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]].
+
The earliest known written evidence for a formal study of ethics can be traced to early Greek civilization, with substantial further development made by Roman and other thinkers of the Classical period. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]].
     
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source of moral authority was of great importance.
 
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source of moral authority was of great importance.
